wikipedia_page.main: Admiral Sir John Reginald Thomas Fullerton,  (10 August 1840 – 29 June 1918) was a Royal Navy officer and courtier.

response: * John Fullerton, appointed 1884The Navy List (1891), p. 264.

On 18 December 1900 Alberta carried the Queen to the Isle of Wight for the last time. Aged 81, and in failing health, the Queen spent Christmas at Osborne, and her condition rapidly declined. Close members of her family were summoned, and on 19 January 1901 Alberta carried Prince Edward and Princess Louisa across the Solent to be at her bedside. Over the next few days Alberta conveyed numerous royal persons and their attendants across to the Isle of Wight, including the Prince of Wales and the Queen's grandson Kaiser Wilhelm II, on the morning of 21 January. Queen Victoria died in the evening of 22 January. After her body had been prepared, Admiral Sir John Fullerton and the officers of Alberta came ashore to pay their respects with the rest of the royal staff and servants.
*Admiral Sir John Fullerton (1840–1918), Royal Navy officer and courtier

Fullerton was the second son of Admiral Sir John Fullerton and entered the Royal Navy himself in 1892 as a cadet in HMS Britannia. He was promoted sub-lieutenant in 1899 and lieutenant in 1900. He specialised as a physical training instructor in early 1903, then joined the new Royal Naval College, Osborne as Inspector of Gymnasia. In 1905 he joined the battleship HMS Renown and in January 1907 transferred to HMS Queen, flagship of the Mediterranean Fleet. In October 1908 he joined the royal yacht, HMY Victoria and Albert, and was promoted commander in 1910. In 1911 he was appointed executive officer of the battleship  in the Mediterranean, and the following year rejoined Osborne.Obituary, The Times, 12 November 1962

In 1901 he married Judith Fullerton, the daughter of Admiral Sir John Fullerton;The Peerage.com they had three sons, named Timothy, Michael and Peter.

In June 1885, he was promoted to captain. He commanded the cruiser  in the 1890 annual manoeuvres.Naval Intelligence. The Times. 19 July 1890. p. 12. Issue 33068. Bainbridge was appointed aide-de-camp to Queen Victoria in March 1897, replacing the promoted Arthur Dalrymple Fanshawe. He was promoted to rear admiral in July 1899, vice John Fullerton. Bainbridge owned the steam ship SS Matador and purchased the yacht Vanadis in April 1901 from the 10th Earl of Wemyss. Totnes Weekly Times. 27 April 1901. p. 2 While sailing aboard Vanadis into Bergen on 9 August 1901, Bainbridge fell ill with apoplexy. He died at 5am the next morning. Lakes Herald. 16 August 1901. p. 2 Besides his naval career, he had also served as a justice of the peace for County Cork.
